tossups.question: In a 1889 novel from this country, the protagonist pursues two women at once, but loses them both after shouting the wrong name in bed. A director from this country was commissioned to make a documentary about fishermen, but combined it with one of this country’s novels to make the “docufiction” film The Earth Trembles. That novel from this country follows a family who go into debt after losing a shipment of lupins and struggle to repurchase the (*) property which titles the English translation of that novel. In a novel from this country, the title lovers escape from their village on a barge to stop Lucia from being forcibly married to Don Rodrigo. This country was home to the authors of The House by the Medlar Tree and The Betrothed. For 10 points, name this country home to Gabriele D’Annunzio, Giovanni Verga and Alessandro Manzoni.

One king of this name had a prime minister who was the target of the epigram “And the suffering people in desperation / now fear you’ll tax them for respiration.” Another king with this name was promised an unspecified Austrian province in the Oñate Treaty, which allowed Austria to claim the Bohemian throne. A king of this name was advised by the Count-duke of Olivares. The most famous king of this name briefly conquered Calais, a former territory of his (*) wife, and appointed Margaret of Parma as governor of a restive territory. That king of this name attempted to crush the Dutch Revolt and married Mary, Queen of Scots. For 10 points, name this common name of Spanish kings, including the current king and another who dispatched the Spanish Armada.

The decarboxylation of this compound leads to the foul-smelling cadaverine and its condensation with alpha-ketoglutarate leads to saccharopine. This amino acid is mutated in the majority of diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma cases and results in the sequestration of PRC2, whose EZH2 domain binds to this amino acid. This amino acid is found at position 27 of the histone H3 protein, whose acetylated version is bound by (*) bromodomains. This amino acid is the first in a sequence that is tagged onto proteins that should not leave the endoplasmic reticulum until it is cleaved off. This amino acid features four methyl groups before terminating with an ammonium, which indicates the epsilon group that often is involved in post-translational modification. For 10 points, name this basic amino acid symbolized K.
tossups.answer: lysine [prompt on K before it is read] <Ed. JS>

tossups.question: The first piece in a collection by this composer begins with the eighth note melody of 5 Gs, down to E, up to F, which is then repeated a tone lower in the next measure. Debussy’s G-minor string quartet is said to have been influenced by this composer’s work of the same genre and key. A five-movement composition by this composer includes sections named for dances like the “Rigaudon” and “Sarabande,” and celebrates the 200th anniversary of the (*) namesake playwright. A piano concerto by this composer opens with a tympani roll and is often compared to one in the same key by Robert Schumann. This composer of Lyric Pieces and From Holberg’s Time wrote a suite which includes movements such as “In the Hall of the Mountain King” and “Morning Mood.” For 10 points, the Peer Gynt suite is by which Norwegian composer?

In daily Varanasi funeral processions, four men carrying the corpse on a stretcher will chant that “the name of” this figure “is true.” During Dusshera [doo-shehr-a], giant effigies of one of this figure’s enemies are burned. The Babri Mosque was destroyed in 1992 because it is believed to have stood where this figure was born. Along with Krishna, this figure is commonly invoked in the “Hare” [HUH-reh] chant and a common (*) greeting among Hindus consists of this figure’s name spoken twice. A typical figurine of this figure, who slew the demon Ravana, shows a kneeling Hanuman serving this figure, his brother, and his wife. For 10 points, Diwali commemorates the return of what avatar of Vishnu from his 14-year exile, whose struggle to rescue his wife Sita is relayed in his namesake Sanskrit epic?

The victorious commander in this conflict quoted Abraham Lincoln in his desire for “binding up the nation’s wounds” and awarded no military medals to its fighters. The ethnic tensions that led to this war were foreshadowed by the Census Crisis. The Mid-West Offensive is often considered a turning point during this war due to one side’s failure to hold bridgeheads over a major river. A year before this conflict broke out, Decree 34 (*) abolishing federalism was announced, sparking a coup that killed Johnson Aguiyi-Ironsi. Yakubu Gowon led one side during this war. Bernard Kouchner was inspired to create Doctors Without Borders by an epidemic of kwashiorkor during this conflict. For 10 points, name this conflict where an autonomous region sought to secede from Africa’s most populous country.
tossups.answer: Biafran War [or Nigerian Civil War] <Ed. JM>

tossups.question: This structure can be exploited using techniques like the House of Mind, the House of Spirit, and the House of Force. The UNIX syscalls “brk” and “sbrk” are used to change the size of this structure. Various “bins”, including a “fast bin”, are used to store free “chunks” in this structure. One method of attacking this structure is named for (*) “spraying” it with user-controlled data. The C function “free” is called on pointers to this structure, and the function “malloc” [MAL-ock] allocates memory on this structure. For 10 points, name this part of memory often contrasted with the stack, which also shares its name with an unrelated tree-like data structure in which every node is greater than or equal to its children.
tossups.answer: heap [accept free store; accept dynamic memory; prompt on “memory”]

tossups.question: A poem asks if one of these things can “sing an aria down these rooms” or “fight with fried potatoes / And yesterday’s garbage ripening in the hall,” after contrasting this word with “feeding a wife” and “satisfying a man.” This word is contrasted with “rent” in the poem “Kitchenette Building.” The lines “Good morning, daddy! / Ain’t you heard?” begin and close a collection titled for these things. The speaker wishes “To whirl and to dance / Till the white day is done” before describing (*) “Night coming tenderly,” in a poem titled “[this thing] Variations.” They name a collection of a Montage of [these things], and a different poem asks whether these things “stink like rotten meat? / Or crust and sugar over-/like a syrupy sweet?” or “dry up / like a raisin in the sun?” For 10 points, Langston Hughes’s “Harlem” asks what happens to which kind of thing “deferred?”
tossups.answer: dreams [or Montage of a Dream Deferred; or “Dream Variations;” or “a dream deferred”] <Ed. JO>

tossups.question: Herbert Yardley’s Cipher Bureau, a predecessor to the NSA, is most famous for spying on participants of a treaty negotiation held in this city. In this city, Hamilton Fish, the Earl de Grey, and John Macdonald agreed that the US should be made to pay damages for illegal fishing in Canadian waters. John D. Hickerson and Theodore Achilles led the drafting of one treaty signed in this city, the North (*) Atlantic Treaty. Another treaty signed in this city allowed the construction of certain weapons in a five to three to one-and-three-quarters ratio; that disarmament treaty named after this city was also known as the Five-Power Treaty after its signatories: the United States, Great Britain, Japan, France, and Italy. For 10 points, name this American city that was the site of a 1921-1922 naval conference called by Warren G. Harding.
tossups.answer: Washington, D.C. [accept either underlined portion; or District of Columbia] <Ed. JM>

tossups.question: Sidney Mintz’s Sweetness and Power applies this thinker’s theories to an analysis of the supply chain of sugar. One anthropologist was inspired by this thinker’s ideas to divide production into the three major modes in the book Europe and the People Without History. He’s not Braudel, but capital-rich countries are identified as core in the world systems theory of a sociologist primarily inspired by this thinker, Immanuel (*) Wallerstein. In the political economy system developed by this thinker, the laws of motion between different fields are analyzed. This formulator of the superstructure discussed the differences between two types of circulation called M-C-M and C-M-C in one work. For 10 points, name this author who inspired a namesake school of anthropology with the theory of historical materialism in his Das Kapital.

The protagonist of this novel fantasizes about using his muffin knife to sever the carotid artery of a female character who was based on a man and who is frequently described as having “greenish” skin. When viewing the room in which a starving friend committed suicide, the protagonist of this novel discovers a paper with his name written on it over and over again. One character in this novel rhapsodizes about El Greco’s View of Toledo during his first dinner with the protagonist and later takes him picking (*) hops. The protagonist of this novel works as a floorwalker at a department store after going broke while trying to get through medical school. That character plans to marry Thorpe Athelny’s daughter after getting over a cruel waitress named Mildred Rogers. For 10 points, name this autobiographical novel about the clubfooted Philip Carey, written by W. Somerset Maugham.

Aromatic varieties of this functional group react with enol ethers to form quinolones in the Povarov reaction. This functional group appears as an intermediate before being hydrolyzed to an aryl ketone in the Houben-Hoesch reaction. Reacting an alkene with hydrazoic acid forms this functional group in the (*) Schmidt reaction, while the aza variant of the Diels-Alder reaction sees this functional group react with dienes to form tetrahydropyridines. Reacting one of these with a Grignard reagent yields a nitrile, and when this functional group’s nitrogen features alkyl or aryl substituents, Schiff bases are formed. For 10 points, name this functional group with a carbon-nitrogen double bond.

After acquiring a business run by Hugh Harman and Rudolf Ising, this business profited from a character named Bosko. In the 1930s, chain gang warden J. Harold Hardy sued this company for defamation. With First National, this business made a savvy bet on the Vitaphone technology used in projects such as Lights of New York. This studio helped develop the 1930s gangster film thanks to star Edward G. Robinson’s role in Little (*) Caesar and James Cagney’s in Scarface. Al Jolson’s singing in this studio’s The Jazz Singer was one of the first successful talkies. An iconic water tower at this firm’s Burbank studio is where the Animaniacs lived. For 10 points, name this Hollywood Studio behind the Harry Potter films and Looney Tunes.
tossups.answer: Warner Brothers [or Warner Bros.; or Warner Bros. Pictures; or Warner Bros. Entertainment Inc; or WB, prompt on Time Warner I guess] <Ed. HB>

tossups.question: One section of this text references the “the pipes of earth” and the “pipes of heaven”. Angus Graham interpreted that section of this text to be about contradictory utterances. A man in this text believes his left arm will turn into a rooster and his butt cheeks will turn into cart wheels. Another parable in this text describes its author pounding on a tub and singing after his wife died. This text is divided into the (*) inner chapters, outer chapters, and miscellaneous chapters. This text attacks the Mohist ideal of objectivity and contains the parable of the useless tree, which shows the usefulness of Hui Shi. In a section of this text, its author doesn’t know if he dreamt of being a butterfly, or a butterfly dreamt of being him. For 10 points, identify this Daoist text from the Warring States Period of China.

. A Slavic god whose Latin name is “Gerovitus” is associated with this domain, ruled the season of Springtime, and had a temple at Wolgast destroyed in 1128. That god of this domain is Jarovit. A different god of this type is often pictured with Ah Puch and sometimes was said to set fire to houses. The festival of Panquetzaliztli was dedicated to a god of this type who was known as the "Turquoise Prince.” This domain ruled by (*) Buluc Chabtan was ruled by a god in another mythology who consumed hearts that were kept in an “eagle jar” and led the Aztecs to a spot where an eagle ate a snake on a cactus. A god of this type got his arm bitten off while during the binding of Fenris. For 10 points, the patron of Tenochtitlan, Huitzilopochtli, [“Hoo-etz-il-pockt-lee”] ruled what phenomenon that was also under the domain of Tyr and Ares?
tossups.answer: war [accept gods of war; prompt on conflict, strife, and other similar answers] <Ed. HB>

tossups.question: This organization supposedly pressured the Pulitzer Board to not award a prize to Dan Morse’s 1994 look at its non-diverse board of directors. In 1983, this organization's headquarters was set on fire by a group it frequently clashed with. The founder of this organization has been jokingly called “The Mother Theresa of Montgomery”(*) by some. The Family Research Council was targeted by gunman Floyd Corkins after reading about the FRC on this group's website. In 2017, it filed a lawsuit for Tanya Gersh against Andrew Anglin, the owner of a website recently pulled off the public internet. Maajid Nawaz controversially ended up on its Intelligence Project list due to his criticisms of Islam. This organization successfully bankrupted several local chapters of the KKK with lawsuits and hate crime penalties. For 10 points, name this non-profit that generates a list of hate groups in the US.
tossups.answer: SPLC [or Southern Poverty Law Center] <Ed. HB>

tossups.question: One member of this family was an "interloping" trader who was arrested in 1683 and 1687 by agents of the British East India Company for negotiating his own trade deals with the Mughals. A politician with this surname resigned when the king refused to support Catholic Emancipation following the Acts of Union that created the United Kingdom. The Ministry of All the (*) Talents was formed after the death of a Prime Minister of this surname during the Napoleonic Wars. One member of this family was nicknamed “the Great Commoner.” A city named for a member of this family is located at the confluence of the Allegheny and Ohio Rivers. For 10 points, name this family, whose "elder" and "younger" members both served as Prime Minister.

As a young man, this artist painted a self-portrait imagining himself at age 100 in which he sits on a divan and is menaced by a creature he especially hated, a spider. This artist incorporated oriental vases and dolls from a curio shop owned by his mother Marie into many of his paintings. This artist’s best known painting was kept rolled up for thirty years and is now at the Getty Museum. This artist represented himself as the title fish in a piece mocking his unfriendly critics titled (*) Skeletons Fighting Over a Pickled Herring. This artist wears a red feathered hat in a crowded canvas depicting himself surrounded by people wearing masks. A procession of mask wearers largely ignore the title figure underneath a banner reading “Vive La Sociale” in another of this artist’s works. For 10 points, name this Belgian artist of Christ's Entry Into Brussels in 1889.
tossups.answer: James Ensor [or James Sidney Edouard, Baron Ensor] <Ed. DS>

tossups.question: In signal processing, a function described by this name between two signals equals the magnitude-squared of the cross-spectral density divided by the product of the power spectral density of each of the two signals. Eigenstates of the annihilation operator are described by this term and include “squeezed” states that attain minimum uncertainty. According to (*) Ginzburg-Landau theory, type-I superconductors have small values for the ratio of the penetration length to the length of this name. One over the bandwidth approximates this phenomenon’s namesake time. Wave function collapse sees the superposition of two states collapsing to one, which describes the loss of this property. For 10 points, monochromatic lasers have what property in which waves have fixed phase difference?
tossups.answer: coherence [accept word forms like coherent; accept coherence function; or coherence time; or coherence length]

tossups.question: This work describes “comfort” as a “stealthy thing that enters the house a guest, and becomes a host, and then a master.” One section of this work describes how people have a “god-self” and a “pygmy-self,” in explaining why they commit crimes. This book gives advice to couples, saying “fill each other’s cup but drink not from one cup” and “let there be spaces in your togetherness.” This book’s title character is repeatedly asked to (*) “speak to us” on various topics like “houses,” “crime and punishment,” and “marriage.” After growing up in a city and observing it for 12 years, this book’s title figure prepares to return home in its first section, “The Coming of the Ship.” In this collection, the residents of Orphalese discuss various topics with Almustafa. For 10 points, name this collection of prose poems by Kahlil Gibran.

(TB). One author from this country had her lobotomy cancelled when she was announced as the winner of one of this country’s highest literary prizes. That author was the subject of the film An Angel at My Table. A short story from this country ends with a guy trying to send back the untouched cream after his companion deserts him at a café. An author from this home country of Ngaio Marsh and Janet (*) Frame wrote about “Jug” and “Con” dispensing with their dead father’s property. That author of “A Dill Pickle” and “The Daughters of the Late Colonel” wrote a story set in this country where Scott’s face seems to say “All is well” after Laura brings his grieving mother a basket of pastries. For 10 points, name this country home to the author of “The Garden Party,” Katherine Mansfield.

bonuses.leadin: A C major five-movement piece of this name composed by Anton Bruckner was considered as a possible finale for his Ninth Symphony. For 10 points each:
answers: Te Deum [or “Te Deum laudamus”; accept “Thee, O God, we praise”]
parts: A performance of a piece of what name celebrating Louis XIV’s recovery from surgery saw a staff strike Jean-Baptiste Lully’s foot?
William Walton’s setting of the Te Deum was named for one of these events in 1952. Handel composed Zadok the Priest for one of these events.
This French baroque composer’s setting of the Te Deum is said to celebrate the 1692 Battle of Steinkirk. This composer wrote the opera The Pleasures of Versailles as composer for Louis XIV’s son.

bonuses.leadin: This phenomenon can be divided into explicit and spontaneous varieties depending on, respectively, whether the equations of motion or the ground state fails to be invariant. For 10 points each:
answers: symmetry breaking [prompt on a partial answer; accept explicit symmetry breaking or spontaneous symmetry breaking]
Mermin-Wagner-Hohenberg-Berezinskii theorem [or Coleman theorem; prompt on partial answers]
bosons [accept Nambu-Goldstone bosons; or Higgs boson]
parts: Name this phenomenon in which small fluctuations acting on a system crossing a critical point prevent said system from becoming invariant under operations such as rotations and translations.

This theorem, under the assumptions of finite temperatures and short-range interactions, states that continuous symmetries cannot be broken in one and two dimensions. The two-dimensional Ising model shows that this theorem does not apply to discrete symmetries.
Proofs of the Mermin-Wagner theorem usually consider the special class of these particles named for Nambu and Goldstone. These particles include a famous one named for Higgs.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about who actually counts as a Jew according to different denominations or texts for 10 points each:
answers: matrilineal descent [accept any answer stating something like the mother is a Jew]
parts: Description acceptable. Text from the Mishnah resulted in the rabbinic law convention among Orthodox and Conservative Jews that only people who convert to Judaism or have Jewish ancestry of this kind are Jewish.

This body of Jewish law is laid out in the Shulchan Aruch. Hard-line Orthodox sects regard complete observance of this law code as necessary for converts to become Jews, which includes their undergoing circumcision and immersion in a mikveh.
According to the halakha, even an observance of these 613 Jewish commandments does not make someone a Jew. These commandments, found in the Torah, are attributed to Rabbi Simlai.

bonuses.leadin: One study of this phenomenon by John Bargh showed people acted slowly when read words related to elderly people. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this effect in which subtle environmental stimuli cause changes to a person’s response to other stimuli. Chapter 4 of Daniel Kahneman’s Thinking Fast and Slow summarizes many studies of this effect, several of which were found to be non-replicable, and Kahneman has since called the study of this effect a “trainwreck.”

Kahneman has shown skepticism towards priming studies because of their sample size. In a 1971 paper, he and this Israeli developer of prospect theory criticized the use of small sample sizes in social psychology research.

Kahneman further conceded that researchers can try to get published by “hacking” the p-value of these kinds of tests. These tests are named after a statement whose null variety can be rejected or not rejected.

bonuses.leadin: Until this practice was banned in the 19th century, newlywed brides from the upper classes would be sent to their husbands with the ohaguro necessary to partake in it. For 10 points each:
answers: geishas [prompt on courtesans; prompt on prostitutes] <Ed. JM>
parts: Identify this practice where Japanese women and later men would soak scraps of iron in a mixture of sake or vinegar and apply it to themselves to make themselves more beautiful.

During the Edo Period, women started buying luxury combs, some of which would be made from this material. Guangzhou craftsmen specialized in making concentric spheres from this material, although state factories making goods from this material in China were closed in 2017.
Women in this profession still apply an "honorable white" paste to their faces. These “art people” train to play the samisen and are skilled in flower arranging and entertaining men.

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer some questions about a certain author’s finances.
parts: This 1837 novel, its author’s first, relates the adventures of a naive gentlemen who travels around observing life. Installments sold just okay until the introduction of amusing Cockney servant Sam Weller, after which it became incredibly popular. However, its author saw none of the money because he had signed away the copyright.

This author of The Pickwick Papers went into the publishing business himself with the magazine Household Words. When sales started to go down, he revived them by using the magazine to publish his shortest novel, Hard Times.

This novel was Dickens’ most profitable in his own lifetime. Characters in this novel include Bradley Headstone, a respectable schoolteacher by day who tries to drown his romantic rival Eugene Wrayburn over the affections of Lizzie.

bonuses.leadin: This man is the alphabetically first namesake of a 1943 experiment, also known as the fluctuation test, which shows that genetic mutations occur in the absence of selection.  For 10 points each:
answers: phages [or American Phage Group; accept bacteriophage]
parts: Name this German biophysicist who names that experiment, along with Salvador Luria.

Delbruck, Luria, and Alfred Hershey were leaders of a group named after these viruses that infect and replicate within bacteria. The Luria-Delbruck Experiment featured E. coli cultures, whose agar contained the T1 examples of these.

The precursors to the Hershey-Chase experiments done by Griffith, and Avery, Oswald, and McCarty used this species of bacteria to study the role of DNA. Griffith used the virulent III-S and non-virulent II-R strains of this species.

bonuses.leadin: This author frequently wore a black veil with two eye holes in it to cover up his horrific case of eczema. For 10 points each:
answers: the Beast is played by the same actor as the antagonist [or reasonable equivalents]
Oedipus Rex [or Oedipus the King] <Ed. DS>
parts: Name this French author who directed the 1946 film version of Beauty and the Beast and wrote about the destructive one-upmanship between siblings Elisabeth and Paul in his novel Les Enfants Terribles.

Cocteau added Freudian themes to his Beauty and the Beast story by making this unusual choice, which only becomes obvious to the audience in the final scenes of the film after the Beast dies and is resurrected as a normal human.

Cocteau wrote the libretto for Stravinsky’s opera adaptation of this play, which had previously been analyzed by Freud. Cocteau’s own adaptation of this play, The Infernal Machine, begins with the appearance of the ghost of the protagonist’s father Laius.

bonuses.leadin: A revised version of the first part of this work was recorded for Columbia in 1958, and the full-length original got two encore performances at Boston's Symphony Hall and at a show in Cleveland a month later.  For 10 points each:
answers: Black, Brown and Beige: A Tone Parallel to the History of the Negro in America [or B, B & B]
parts: Identify this long, three movement tone poem. The first of these movements is further subdivided into “Work Song,” “Come Sunday,” and “Light.”
Black, Brown and Beige is a long piece by this jazz pianist from Washington, D.C., whose band recorded standards such as “It Don’t Mean a Thing (If It Ain’t Got That Swing)”.

This song, a collaboration between Ellington and Barney Bigard, was reworked from a Lorenzo Tio creation. Its singer’s title emotion “goes stealin' down to my shoes” ever since “my baby said goodbye.”

bonuses.leadin: One metal song of this type featured the members of Spinal Tap and guitar solos from the likes of George Lynch and Buck Dharma. For 10 points each:
answers: charity single [or charity song; or charity album; or charity record]
parts: The 1985 track "Stars" was what type of song?

This song kicked off the charity single craze and raised money for famine relief in Ethiopia.  Thusly, a common refrain in this song is “feed the world”, and this song ends with “Let them know it’s [the title time].”

Another Christmas-themed charity song is “I Feel It in My Bones” by this Las Vegas band, whose 2007 song “Don’t Shoot Me Santa” also had its proceeds sent to AIDS charities. This band released songs like “Run for Cover” in 2017.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about some saline bodies of water in Central Asia. For 10 points each,
parts: This lagoon, which adjoins a port that Sapurmanat Niyazov renamed after himself, seasonally fluctuates between being a lake and a bay.
When it isn’t a lake of its own, Karabogaz Kol is a bay of this sea, the largest inland body of water in the world.
The Aral Sea is shrinking due to its draining by two Soviet canals built to irrigate this crop, Uzbekistan’s main export.

bonuses.leadin: This man introduced paper money into France and turned the General Bank into the Royal Bank in 1718.  For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this Scottish finance minister, who resigned and went into exile in Venice following the 1718 collapse of a major bubble.
The aforementioned bubble was named for this territory, which shares its name with a modern-day US state. The Sieur de la Salle explored the delta of a river of this name in the late 17th century.

The Mississippi Bubble burst following the demands of a prince from this house to sell twenty-five million shares in the company. A “great” general from this family fought with the Spanish at the Battle of the Dunes, tried to get himself elected King of Poland, and led the army of Louis XIV at the 1674 Battle of Seneffe.

bonuses.leadin: Along with William Trotter, this man names a theorem that gives a precise bound on the number of incidences between a set of points and a set of lines. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this mathematician, who proved that any sufficiently large graph has an epsilon-regular partition, a result known as his regularity lemma.

Szemerédi used his regularity lemma to prove a celebrated theorem stating that any set of integers with positive upper density contains arbitrarily large examples of these things. which are sequence with a constant difference between pairs of elements.

This other Hungarian mathematician has a namesake conjecture on arithmetic progressions generalizing Szemerédi’s theorem. This extremely prolific mathematician names a number measuring the collaboration distance between him and any other person.

bonuses.leadin: In this story, the school bully Mark owns an Obi-Wan Kenobi action figure that can only swing its arms around and say “Use the Force!” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Ken Liu story, in which the narrator’s mother makes origami animals that come to life, including a tiger nicknamed Laohu. This story also titles the 2016 collection in which it appears.

Ken Liu also translated this Liu Cixin [tsih-SHEEN] novel, the first in the Remembrance of Earth’s Past trilogy, into English. In this novel, the Trisolarans invade Earth because they cannot predict the Stable and Chaotic Eras of their own planet.

In 2012, “The Paper Menagerie” became the first work of fiction to win all three major science fiction awards: the World Fantasy Award, the Nebula Award, and this award, also given to The Three-Body Problem.

bonuses.leadin: This trait is divided into the qualities of impetuosity and weakness and then further classified by the causes of pleasure or anger. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ancient Greek term for weakness of will, which is contrasted with a word that means “in power.” An example of this trait is when someone chooses something when they know something else is the best.

This philosopher’s 1970 paper “How is Weakness of the Will Possible?” answered the title question by asserting that irrationality is real. He formulated the Swampman thought experiment in “Knowing One’s Own Mind.”

Aristotle’s characterization of the impulse to do bad that overcomes reason during akrasia resembles this philosopher’s view that evil actions were only possible due to ignorance. In Plato’s Protagoras, this philosopher argues against a sophist.

bonuses.leadin: The first one of these was invented in 1650 by German scientist Otto von Guericke, the conductor of the Magdeburg hemispheres experiment. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these devices, whose momentum transfer varieties include ones named diffusion and turbomolecular. These devices remove gas molecules from a fixed volume to decrease pressure to nearly zero torr.

Cryopumps, or cryogenic pumps, are vacuum pumps that feature low temperature surfaces that can be covered by zeolites or this substance. This molecular sieve can be made from decomposing sources like peat, wood, and coal at high temperatures and features pores that help raise the surface area for reactions.
The large surface area of activated charcoal makes it ideal for adsorption, which is modeled by this man’s isotherm, which assumes adsorbates are an ideal gas.

bonuses.leadin: Historians debate whether the lives of these people improved with the reforms of Pavel Kiselyov during the reign of Nicholas I. For 10 points each:
answers: Russian crown serfs [or Russian state serfs; or state peasants; or crown peasants; prompt on serfs; prompt on peasants]
parts: Identify these Russian subjects, distinct from those of the appanages and those of the land. Despite the frequent transfers of these people to the nobility, they constituted over 40% of Russia’s population by the 1850s.
This Russian emperor freed the serfs and was assassinated by members of the People’s Will in 1881.

After being forced to cultivate this crop, serfs in Viatka Province protested that its “seed are antichrist,” because they thought it derived from the apple that tempted Eve. They’re not plums, but the War of the Bavarian Succession is sometimes named for this food.

bonuses.leadin: Identify the following about the career of British artist James Wilson Carmichael. For 10 points each:
answers: marine paintings [or seascapes; or ship paintings; or naval paintings]
parts: Carmichael was best known for painting these types of scenes, and even published a book on how to make them. Thomas Birch was the first prominent American painter of these scenes, and Princeton's Art Museum displays a Fitz Henry Lane painting in this genre set at Gloucester and shrouded in fog.

Another Carmichael book explored the art of marine painting in this medium. Thomas Girtin inaugurated the English tradition of landscapes in this medium, in which pigments are applied to the paper surface via a brush soaked with the namesake liquid.

Carmichael's painting HMS Erebus and Terror in the Antarctic is similar in theme to The Sea of Ice by this other painter. This Romantic artist's other marine-themed paintings include the allegorical The Stages of Life, in which the five differently-aged people in the foreground are contrasted with the ships in the distance.

bonuses.leadin: Privates Bartle and Murph serve in this war in Kevin Powers’ novel The Yellow Birds. For 10 points each:
answers: Tim O’Brien [or William Timothy O’Brien] <Ed. JO>
parts: Name this war, also the setting of Phil Klay’s collection Redeployment. In a Ben Fountain novel, Billy Lynn is hailed as a hero and invited to the Cowboys’ Thanksgiving game when his actions in this war are caught on camera.

Dakotah Lister loses an arm while serving in Iraq in this author’s short story “Tits-Up in a Ditch.” In another story, she wrote about the homosexual relationship between Ennis del Mar and Jack Twist, who work at a Wyoming ranch.
Another work of contemporary war fiction is The Things They Carried, a collection of Vietnam War stories by this author.

bonuses.leadin: After sacking Fort Caroline and massacring its Huguenot inhabitants, this man had their bodies hung on trees inscribed with the phrase “Not as Frenchmen, but as heretics.” For 10 points each:
answers: Pedro Menéndez de Avilés [prompt on de Avilés]
parts: Name this Spanish Captain-General, who was tasked by Philip II with preventing French settlement in the Florida area. He established the colony of La Florida after fighting off the French settler Jean Ribault.
In 1565, Menéndez founded this oldest still occupied city on the continental United States.
Santa Elena, the temporary capital of La Florida, is near Port Royal and the Marine Corps Recruit Depot of Parris Island in this modern-day state.
